The point I want to make is that the figure is increasing. Unlike the statements to which I refer on pages 8 and 13, when one reaches page 26, one realises that the amount rose by €77 million. The overall performance of the bank is also in decline and that is of concern to the people who made the investment, particularly in the context of the fact that the underlying loss increased from €722 million to €907 million.
I am concerned by the statement on page 9 to the effect that Bank of Ireland is 73% a property-based institution. That is exactly what got the country into the trouble in which it finds itself.
The Senator is going to run out of time, without Mr. Boucher being able to provide replies.
Will Mr. Boucher comment on the public interest directors at the bank? How much are these individuals paid? Do they make any contribution at all to solving the problems we are discussing?

The directors' remuneration is set out in the annual report. I do not have the information, but I can supply a page number. Under company law, the directors are all obliged to work in the best interests of the company. The Minister for Finance made an announcement in that regard in answer to a question in the Dáil. All the directors are expected to challenge and contribute to the board.
Does Senator Barrett wish to ask other questions?
No, I am finished with my questions. I am just listening for answers.
What makes public interest directors different from the other directors on the board?
They do not have to stand for re-election. That is the primary difference between them and the other directors. For that reason and under Stock Exchange rules, they are not considered independent.
Their primary client is the bank, it is not actually the State.
Under company law, they are required to act in the best interests of the company.
Therefore, they are not really personal interest directors, as such, particularly if they are required to obey the law.

If I might move from the particular to the general, Bank of Ireland's future is tied up with that of the country. We have a vested interest in the recovery of the country. Our business will not recover unless the country recovers. I suspect that we are 80% to 90% aligned in respect of these goals. We would have different-----

That is not the question Senator Barrett posed. He inquired as to what made personal interest directors different from other directors on the board. Mr. Boucher's response was that under company law, they were required to behave and display a duty of care in the same fashion as the other directors. They are not, therefore, really any different from the other directors.
They are not private interest directors; they are public interest directors.
They do not report to the State, the Minister for Finance or, under its terms of reference, this committee. This means that they are no different from the other directors.
The primary difference between them and the other directors is that they do not stand for re-election.

Which is a great position in which to be. In terms of their day-to-day work, they do not do anything different from the other directors. I would love to be in a position where I would not be obliged to stand for re-election at the conclusion of the term of each Dáil. However, that is not the way it works. There are rules to which the people concerned are obliged to adhere and, as such, there really is no difference between them and the other directors other than the fact that they are not obliged to stand for re-election.
All of the directors-----

I wish to make a proposal to the effect that we should call the public interest directors to come before us at the earliest opportunity. Is that agreed? Agreed. Does Senator Barrett wish to add anything?

I take it that the performance of the bank is declining, as shown on page 8, that the underlying losses are up to €907 million from €722 million and that the impairment charges are rising, as shown on page 26. Will Mr. Boucher confirm the figures?
Impairment charges are reducing on a half-year basis.
Then how come they go up by €77 million when one goes to page 26?
The systems go to page 30, which is the market disclosure. We disclose half year and half year and then against the preceding period.
This is exactly the half year period, H1 201 2 and H1 201 1. It went from €901 million to €978 million. I presume the numbers Mr. Boucher has supplied to us are correct.
They are verified numbers, taken from our annual report and statement.
How much time do I have?
Deputy O’Donnell has about six minutes and then I will call Deputy Ross. We will conclude at that point.

Limited time is available. I know Mr. Boucher well because I brought the CEOs of the banks before the finance committee in 2008. I am struck by their lack of moral compass. Nothing has changed although we are in a completely different space now. Mr. Boucher is not answering questions. I will put a couple of questions to him. First, have the top level CEOs in the banks taken any reduction in salary to date?
Yes.
When?
It was disclosed in the accounts in 2009.
Have any reductions been introduced since then?
There has been a reduction in my pension arrangements, as was publicly disclosed in 2010.
What pension is the former CEO, Mr. Brian Goggin, in receipt of currently?
I am not aware of that. I do not know.
It is publicly disclosed.
I can get the disclosure but I am not aware of it.
I think it is of the order of €300,000 but I hear someone say that it is €650,000.
I will get the exact disclosure.
Did the bank have a shortfall in its pension fund?
We have a deficit in the fund.
How is the bank funding that?
The deficit is an accounting deficit. It is driven by liabilities and measures. We look at the assets and the liabilities.
How is the bank funding the shortfall? The bank is required to fund the deficit in the pension scheme.

Over a period of time. Primarily, there has been a combination of a change in benefits which were agreed in 2010 and 2011, freezing of future payments and changing the liabilities and assets in the fund.
My question is whether any of the shortfall is being funded by the bank itself.
The bank has a contractual obligation to meet certain funds.

Is it correct to say that some taxpayers’ money that went into Bank of Ireland is going to fund the deficit on a pension scheme that is paying €650,000 to the CEO that was in place at the time the bank had to depend on the kindness of taxpayers to bail it out?
Yes, I think so. The money was from all the shareholders.
Am I correct in the assertion that Mr. Brian Goggin is on a higher pension than Mr. Boucher’s current salary?
Based on the information Deputy Ross has found, that is the case.
It is a pretty close run thing.
Second, if Mr. Boucher were to retire in the morning, under the rules of the scheme, what percentage of salary would be given by way of pension?
It is two thirds of final salary under defined benefit.
If one were to work on the basis of those figures, that is €620,000 divided by three and multiplied by two, which means he would be on a pension of more than €400,000.
Potentially, if I work until I reach my full benefit.
Given the situation, does Mr. Boucher not find that mind boggling? He has the distinction of being the only top level management CEO still in place from the time of the crisis.
When did Bank of Ireland introduce 100% mortgages for home owners?
I cannot recall exactly. I think it was early 2006.

In terms of the loans in arrears for more than 90 days I see a spike in 2006 and 2007. In 2005 it was 9.8%. In 2006 it was 12.3% and in 2007 it was 12.5%. Bank of Ireland is responsible for many of those people being in arrears. It is not good enough to come before the committee and say that the bank must recover the maximum amount of loans. The bank irresponsibly gave out 100% loans at that time. Has the bank given any write-offs to mortgage holders recently?
We have provided against the mortgages-----
No, I am asking whether write-offs have been provided to individuals.
I have given the answer I can give.
What is the total amount of money put into Bank of Ireland by taxpayers?
The total investment by the taxpayer is €4.8 billion. The sum of €0.5 billion-----

A portion of the €4.8 billion is funding a pension of €650,000 a year to Mr. Brian Goggin, former CEO, and the salary for Mr. Boucher, who was previously deputy CEO with responsibility for retail mortgages, to the tune of approximately €620,000 plus benefits, which would bring him close to €900,000. Mr. Boucher is probably in line for a pension of the order of €400,000. He is clearly well prepared on a PR level to answer no questions. Where is his moral compass in all of this? The problem is that Bank of Ireland sold products during the boom that people could not afford.
Is Deputy O’Donnell making a concluding comment or putting a question?
I am putting a question and then a final comment.
The Deputy should put his question.

The question is whether the bank will deal with mortgage holders to ensure their mortgages are sustainable. The second question is important. It has not been asked previously. How much of the €3.5 billion target for lending to SMEs was new lending not restructured lending?
The question was asked by Deputy O’Donnell’s colleague, Deputy Dara Murphy.
New and increased lending amounted to €3.5 billion.
No, just new lending. I am not interested in restructured lending.
I have said we do not count restructured lending in our targets. We do not get revenue from restructured loans.
When AIB was before the committee yesterday it informed us that €600 million of the €3.5 billion was completely new lending, not restructured lending.
We are not AIB.
I am asking Mr. Boucher a question.
It was €3.5 billion.
So €3.5 billion was completely new lending.
This is a public disclosure. I am conscious of my public disclosures.
Is Mr. Boucher saying that none of it was restructured.

Some of it may be but to a statistical margin of error, which in our view is less than 3%. I can say with confidence that 97% of the total is new lending. I believe it is 100% but I cannot verify that. This is a market disclosure. Any comments I make in a public forum are market disclosures.
Mr. Boucher is saying that €3.5 billion is completely new lending.
It is new and increased lending.
Could Mr. Boucher tell me about the mortgage holders?
Deputy O’Donnell-----
Will Bank of Ireland engage in the restructuring-----
Excuse me. The Chair is speaking to Deputy O’Donnell.
In the limited time-----
I do not care about the limited time. As soon as I open my mouth Deputy O’Donnell should stop talking. If he can make the point succinctly I will allow it.
Will Bank of Ireland engage in the restructuring of mortgages and will Mr. Boucher take a reduction in salary and will-----
That is a second question. I am moving on.
These are important questions.
I am moving on.
What about the question on mortgage holders?
Deputy O’Donnell must please respect the Chair.
We are engaging every day with mortgage holders to restructure and modify their loans.
Will Mr. Boucher take a reduction in his salary?
My salary is put to the shareholders.

That question has been put before. The Gallery has heard it enough this morning. Before I bring in Deputy Shane Ross, Mr. Boucher must clarify a few points. There has been wide acceptance that his engagement with the committee on a number of questions has been at a minimalist level, if I could even call it that. I wish to put that on record.

An issue has been outstanding since Mr. Boucher came before the committee and I still have not got my head around it. A question was put to Mr. Boucher, as it was put to AIB, on the absolute cost of the institution reducing the standard variable rate on domestic mortgages by 0.5%. The figure we got from AIB yesterday afternoon was that private dwelling houses on its domestic book is worth approximately €14.3 billion and a 0.5% reduction would result in a loss of €71 million to AIB. On the figures Mr. Boucher gave us this morning, the domestic book of Bank of Ireland is approximately €21 billion and if the bank reduced its standard variable rate by 0.5% its loss would be €29 million, approximately a third less than AIB. Could he explain to us how it is the case that a smaller loss would be incurred following a 0.5% reduction given that the loan book is bigger?

The trackers are excluded. We have fixed-rate mortgages and standard variable-rate mortgages. We disclose the trackers. With regard to the standard rate and variable rate, our figure may be lower than that of Allied Irish Banks, but I am not familiar with the numbers of the latter.
As far as I know, there is blending also.
We have fixed-rate mortgages in addition to standard variable-rate mortgages.

Another issue relates to a question put to Mr. Boucher by Deputy Donnelly. Yesterday afternoon, AIB was asked the number of mortgages with a shortfall that it has allowed to be surrendered voluntarily and its policy on shortfalls. We seem to have received a very vague response from Bank of Ireland on the matter. The AIB officials advised us yesterday afternoon that 140 properties were surrendered with a mortgage shortfall. The response of Bank of Ireland to date has been that it has a responsibility to maximise the recovery of all moneys owed by customers and that it has a comprehensive arrangement and process to work with customers to find solutions that can work for them and the bank in this regard. Bank of Ireland states that, as a last resort, it may have to instigate a formal legal process. That is not answering the question; rather, it is symptomatic of some of the replies we received this morning. It indicates the bank is not really engaging with the process in a serious manner. It also means it is not engaging with this committee in a serious manner, which is of equal concern to me. What is Bank of Ireland's position on the issue of voluntary surrenders where there are mortgage shortfalls? What is the bank doing in this regard?
The total number of repossessions or surrenders for the half-year was 200.
I have a figure of approximately 120.
There is a mixture of owner-occupier and buy-to-let properties.

Why could the delegates not have given us that answer at the start of this morning's proceedings without our having to endure a lengthy rigmarole? The question was put to the delegates very simply and we now have the answer.
I am sorry if I missed that specific question.
There is a big X across it. It is a market disclosure.

Mr. Boucher has still not answered the question that specifically concerns surrender. The delegation listed a total number of surrenders or repossessions but did not answer the question on the level of debt surrender involved.
Could Mr. Boucher answer that?
We deal with customers on an individual basis and therefore do not disclose the figures.
Bank of Ireland does disclose them. Mr. Boucher disclosed the figures to us before. He is treating this committee with contempt today.
I am not.
He most certainly is.
I am not. I must conform with the requirements of the Stock Exchange on disclosures.
Is Mr. Boucher telling me that, by law, he is not allowed to tell this committee how much he has or has not surrendered?
I am conforming with the requirements I have in the Stock Exchange.
Is that an interpretation or did Mr. Boucher get a legal ruling?
I do not have lawyers sitting beside me when answering every question.
Have the guidelines changed since Bank of Ireland provided us with the information on the last occasion?
I have given the answer I can give.
Mr. Boucher is very welcome. I declare an interest in that I am a small shareholder in Bank of Ireland.
Is Mr. Boucher a member of the board?
Yes.
How did the board choose the new governor?

We have a nominations and governance committee. It went to an external third party, which identified potential candidates. The potential candidates were reviewed by the committee and a recommendation was put to the board. When the candidate agreed to be considered, there was consultation with the FSA, because we have a large business, and then the candidate went through the process to meet the fitness and probity requirements of the Central Bank of Ireland.
How much did Mr. Boucher know about the prospective new governor when his name was submitted to the board?
There was full disclosure of all issues that were considered to be relevant.
This is important because the appointee is, I believe, on €400,000 per year. Was Mr. Boucher aware of his record in Lloyds TSB?
There was full disclosure of his entire career.
Was Mr. Boucher aware that he was the insurance director?
Yes.
Was Mr. Boucher aware that he was insurance director during the biggest scandal pertaining to payment protection insurance that has ever arisen in the United Kingdom?
He was a director of Lloyds Bank and was in charge of the insurance division.
Was Mr. Boucher aware that there was a huge scandal pertaining to payment protection insurance while the individual was in charge?
We were well aware of the disclosures that Lloyds had made.
Was that disclosure made?
Lloyds had made its disclosures prior to the appointment of the chairman.
Was Mr. Boucher aware of the insurance mis-selling scandal that was breaking?
In its annual report, Lloyds Bank had disclosed-----
Was Mr. Boucher aware of it? I know about Lloyds Bank.
We would read the annual report.
Was Mr. Boucher aware of it?
We were aware of the disclosures that Lloyds Bank made regarding payment protection insurance.
Was Mr. Boucher happy to appoint someone who had been accountable when mis-selling was occurring?
Deputy Ross is starting to make certain inferences.
I am not inferring anything; it is on the public record.
Deputy Ross is doing so.

It is on the public record. Lloyds stated that accountability was important. When making the appointment, was Mr. Boucher aware that the individual's bonus was reduced as a result of what had occurred?
Yes. As I stated, there was full disclosure.

Mr. Boucher, therefore, was happy to appoint someone who lost a bonus in a bank, which, as Mr. Boucher will know, is very difficult to do. I refer to the appointment, as governor of Bank of Ireland, of an individual who lost a bonus at the time of an emerging mis-selling scandal. Today, it has been revealed that the payment protection insurance bill of Lloyds has ballooned to €5.3 billion. Is Mr. Boucher aware of that?
Yes.
Yet Bank of Ireland still appointed the person as governor.
We made the appointment bearing in mind the full disclosures, the references we received and the fitness and probity regime of the Central Bank of Ireland, and we did so in consultation with the FSA.
Is Mr. Boucher happy that Bank of Ireland has a governor who is fit for office in the circumstances that obtain?
Yes.
What is the current position of Bank of Ireland on payment protection insurance?
We are carrying out a review of payment protection.
Has there been mis-selling?
A review will determine whether there was.
What is Mr. Boucher's view on that?
We are having a review; that is what we are doing.
It is widely expected that a massive amount of mis-selling of payment protection insurance in Ireland, including by Bank of Ireland, will be revealed. What is Mr. Boucher's view on that?

We must examine the total quantum of payment protection insurance policies that Bank of Ireland sold. If there was any mis-selling, it would be serious, but, based on any information available to me, we do not have a market disclosure requirement.

It is absolutely extraordinary that Bank of Ireland should appoint as a governor somebody who had lost his bonus in Lloyds in a payment protection insurance scandal. There are now circumstances in which the bank is investigating itself in respect of payment protection insurance. The board made its appointment in the full awareness that the individual concerned, while not necessarily culpable, was the director in charge of insurance when the scandal arose. That should be noted by this committee.
I thank Mr. Boucher, Ms Carragher and Mr. McLoughlin for appearing before the committee for the third of our modules on banking, which we have considered over the past two days.
The joint committee adjourned at 1.20 p.m. until 2 p.m. on Wednesday, 7 November 2012.
